awd_titl_txt: Semiparametric Estimation and Inference in Partially Identified Econometric Models
awd_abstract_narration:
This award funds research in statistical methods for the analysis of economic data. The goal is to expand the scope of the existing statistical theory that explains the properties of estimation and inference methods for a partially identified model with set identified parameters.

The research clarifies the main challenges to expanding the scope of the existing theory of semiparametric inference, develops new approaches to overcome these challenges, and develops practical suggestions for constructing asymptotically efficient estimators within semiparametric models.  The research develops new methods that are robust against lack of identification, robust against misspecification, and asymptotically efficient within semiparametric models.  

Broader impacts will come from the use of these methods to evaluate the results of a variety of government and business decisions.  The PI will make software code available to other researchers who want to use these new methods.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Social and Economic Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The main outcomes of the project are as follows. First, for a class of semiparametric partially identified models, the PI developed inference methods that extend the scope of semiparametric inference for point identified models. In particular, the PI provided conditions under which, the support function of the identified set can be estimated in an efficient manner paralleling the classic semiparametric approach. The PI also provided some examples for which such semiparametrically efficient estimators do not exist, and considered possible ways to overcome the challenge. Second, for models that involve selection mechanisms such as equilibrium selection, the PI and collaborators developed inference methods that are robust to the presence of such infinite dimensional nuisance parameters. In particular, the developed inference methods are shown to be robust to heterogeneity and dependence of observations that arise from the incompleteness of such models. Third, for a class of models characterized by finitely many moment inequalities, the PI and collaborators developed an inference framework that allows to construct a confidence interval for a particular function of the parameter. More details on each of the outcomes are provided below.

Regarding the first outcome, the paper “Asymptotic Efficient Estimation of Weighted Average Derivatives with an Interval Censored Variable,” Econometric Theory (forthcoming) studied a general regression model where either an outcome variable or a covariate is interval-valued, which leads to set identification of the regression function. Although the regression function is not identified, bounds can be derived for the weighted average derivatives of the regression function. The PI has shown that the identified set of the weighted average derivative is compact and convex hence admits a characterization through its support function, a unique function on the unit sphere that characterizes the identified set through locations of its supporting hyperplanes. This characterization then allowed the PI to investigate semiparametric estimation of the identified set. In particular, the PI has found that a semiparametric efficiency bound exists when the outcome variable is interval-valued. The PI then constructed an efficient estimator that achieves this bound mean regression for a wide range of weights. This extended the previous version of the paper supported by SES-1230071. These results show that one may obtain robustness against misspecification of regression function by studying weighted average derivatives and that the theory of semiparametric efficiency can be extended to a leading example of partially identified models. The PI also analyzed settings where regular estimation of support function is not possible. This arises in the case of interval censoring on a covariate. In such settings, an alternative estimation framework is desirable. The PI explored several possibilities including estimation of a "regularized" version of the support function.

Regarding the second outcome, in the paper “Robust Con?dence Regions for Incomplete Models”, Econometrica, 84(5), (2016) 1799–1838, the PI worked with collaborators and developed an inference framework that allows to construct robust confidence regions in incomplete economic models. In such models, the equilibrium selection mechanism becomes an infinite-dimensional nuisance parameter, which may be heterogeneous and dependent across cross-sectional units. This raises a non-trivial challenge for making inference for (typically finite-dimensional) structural parameters. The PI and collaborators have shown that a novel asymptotic framework, in particular a new central limit theorem for belief measures, can be developed, which does not depend on the nuisance parameter (selection mechanism). This asymptotic framework is then used to construct robust confidence regions. Monte Carlo experiments then confirmed enhanced robustness compared to existing methods.

Regarding the third outcome, in the paper “Confidence Intervals for Projections of Partially Identi?ed Parameters,” the PI worked with collaborators and developed an inference framework that allows to construct a confidence interval for a scalar parameter in models characterized by finitely many moment inequalities. The scalar parameter can be a component of a parameter vector or a smooth functional of it. The semiparametric setting where the model involves an infinite dimensional parameter is considered in another paper “Confidence Intervals for Optimal Values when Objective and Constraints are Estimated”. The confidence interval is based on the projection of a confidence region, which relaxes the sample moment restrictions by a suitably chosen critical level. The paper proposed a novel way to compute this critical level, which is based on linear programs defined over bootstrap replications. This confidence interval is shown to be less conservative than projections of existing confidence regions. The PI and collaborators have further shown that the cost for computing the projections can be mitigated by applying a response surface method, a computational technique to solve optimization problems involving computationally expensive functions. Computer programs are provided through the PI's website.

 


Last Modified: 12/29/2016
Modified by: Hiroaki Kaido
